episode.title: Hartford Underwriters Ins. Company v. Union Planters Bank, N.A.

section.heading: Argument of G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 99-409, the Hartford Underwriters Insurance Company v. the Union Planters Bank.
Mr. Brunstad.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

In the century preceding the enactment of the Bankruptcy Code in 196... 1978, this Court and other Federal courts recognized and enforced the rule that an unpaid administrative claimant in a bankruptcy case can come to court and have his or her claim paid if the expense benefited the secured party.
The Federal courts also recognized the rule that a trustee who pays a claim may come and seek to charge the secured party's collateral if there was a benefit to the secured party.

In enacting section 506(c) of the Bankruptcy Code, Congress recognized the right of the trustee, and the issue before the Court today is whether Congress' recognition of the right of the trustee was therefore intended to abrogate the other pre-code practice, which is that the administrative claimant could come to court and have the claim paid.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So you're simply arguing that if the code says nothing, the pre-code practice applies, notwithstanding something like 506(c)?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

As the Court stated 2 years ago in the Cohen case, cited in our brief, at 523 U.S. at 221, we will not read the Bankruptcy Code to erode past bankruptcy practice absent a clear indication that Congress intended such a departure.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, here, Congress said the trustee--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --can bring it, and it doesn't talk about the creditor, so maybe that's a change.
I mean, it's pretty clear language.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, it is, Your Honor, but I think that the part that Congress recognized was the tip of the iceberg.
As this Court made clear in the Wilson case, which we cite in our brief, the rule which this Court recognized was that the unpaid administrative claimant could come forward and have the claim paid.
Now, we know under the Bankruptcy Code that Congress will codify some of the equitable doctrines that preceded its enactment, and yet this Court has recognized other equitable--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I mean, this just looks like pretty clear language.
Did your client ask the trustee to take action?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Actually, Your Honor, yes, my client did.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: And the trustee's position was that the trustee had no interest in this case and would not pursue it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Could you have asked the judge to instruct the trustee to exercise his discretion to collect the... to impose the surcharge?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, we could have asked the Bankruptcy Court to do that, but we think that the... it would have been futile, because the trustee had no funds whatsoever to engage in litigation with the secured party.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So that it would have been abuse, an abuse of discretion for the trustee to go ahead and seek the surcharge?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: It would have been, Your Honor, completely futile, plus I think Your Honor would have to recognize in this case that the trustee having no interest in recovery because the trustee had not paid the claim in the first place, one could argue that the trustee having no interest and no incentive and no ability, it simply could not have happened.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Did the trustee in your view in this case have the discretion either to seek the surcharge or not to seek the surcharge?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if the trustee had wanted to do so for free, certainly the trustee could have pursued the claim.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Do you think, if you were the counsel for the trustee, you would have told the trustee that he has discretion not to pursue the surcharge?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I would, because the State of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So now we're in the position where the code says, with its... within the trustee's discretion not to pursue the surcharge, and yet the creditor can force it.
That seems a little odd to me.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, our position is not that the creditor can force the trustee to do it.
Our position is that the creditor can pursue the claim directly.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It still seems odd to me.
If the trustee has the discretion not to do so, for the creditor to force it, it seems to me to be in effect controlling the discretion of the trustee.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: I think perhaps, Your Honor, the question here is not whether the trustee has discretion.
It would be whether the trustee has the ability.
In this case, the trustee having no funds to litigate with the secured party simply could not pursue the claim.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If you had had a prior arrangement with the trustee... I don't know whether you did or not... could an action be brought in State court on the basis of representations?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: We think, Your Honor, that the remedy here is a remedy under the bankruptcy laws.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, I didn't... that's not the question I asked you.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought maybe the Eighth Circuit had reserved the question of whether there was some right you had to go into Federal court on diversity or State law.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, that the Eighth Circuit, the en banc decision was merely saying that the only question here is whether there is a question under Federal law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What did the panel opinion say?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: The panel opinion, Your Honor, said that we had the right under section 506(c).
There was no mention of any alternative right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Had you brought any claims in the district court, or any other court?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, we had not.
This is the exclusive means of recovery which we are--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I'm curious about a prior question about what 506(c) covers.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The text of 506(c) says the trustee may recover from property securing an allowed secured claim the reasonable, necessary costs and expenses of preserving or disposing of such property, and I think we're dealing here with Workman's Comp--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --premiums that were incurred after the original Chapter 11 proceeding was begun--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --in an attempt to keep the business going.
It didn't have anything to do with a cost and expense of preserving the real property, did it?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: It did, Your Honor.

In this case the assets in question were operating businesses... gas stations, restaurants... and in order to operate those businesses the debtor had to have Worker's Comp insurance or it could not operate at all, so but for the provision of the insurance there would have been no operation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr.--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Yes, but if they operate at a loss, that's not much of a benefit to the secured creditor.
That's the whole problem, is these people have been operating.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think that the difference is that between liquidation value and going concern value of the gas station.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, put it this way.

I'm not sure... I mean, if your client had been hired to go paint the building, or to repair the plumbing, I can understand how it would fit under 506(c), but to incur an expense for paying these premiums for Workman's Comp to run the business, as opposed to actually enhancing the real property or the building, I'm not sure I see how it fits under 506 at all--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --instead of 503(a).

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, you never get to 506 unless you go through 503.
503 allows the administrative expense and creates a class of administrative expense claimants.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Presumably your client is within that general category.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: There is no dispute, Your Honor, that our claim was allowed as a proper administrative expense.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But you just want to go now against the real property because that's the only thing there is, I guess.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.
506(c) articulates--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --a priority for certain claims.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Okay, but why doesn't it... isn't it limited to something that actually enhances the property as opposed to the broader 503 claim?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, in this case it's undisputed that our claim provided a benefit to the secured party, and the reason that it did was because the value which the bank realized from the sale of these businesses as a going concern was actually much greater than the value that they would have received if the gas station had shut down.
Picture the storage tanks under a gas station which is not operating or generating revenue.
Typically, those operations sell for very little money.

If, however, you have an operating store, and some of these stores are, in fact, still operating, but with different owners, the value is much more, so the bank got the benefit of the difference in value because the debtor was able to operate in a going concern value and those values were preserved.
That is, of course, one of the purposes of Chapter 11.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Brunstad, I have--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Who can speak to engage a client such as yours to continue?
Is it the trustee?
Do you have to have an arrangement with the trustee?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think Your Honor should understand that the trustee and creditors are adversaries, and that it would not be... it would be unseemly in the least for a creditor, who is adversary to a trustee, to have to hire the adversary to pursue the creditor's claims.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but in the first place, after bankruptcy, who authorizes your client to continue paying for Workman's Compensation?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I see.
Well, in this case, Your Honor, our client did not even know of the bankruptcy.
The debtor concealed that fact from us, so we've continued to provide the services without knowledge of the bankruptcy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Without any authorization from the trustee?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it was authorized, Your Honor, but in the Chapter 11 context it doesn't quite work that way.
What happens is that when the debtor, who is in possession of all of the estate, the case is filed, the debtor continues to operate as it had.
Section 1108 of the Bankruptcy Code provides for the continued operation of the businesses, and the ordinary expenses which the debtor would incur in operating the businesses continued to be paid.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, but is the debtor authorized to incur expenses which will be ultimately classified as administrative expenses?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and that... expenses that are incurred in the ordinary course, the debtor is authorized by statute to continue to incur those expenses, and in this case what we have, Your Honor, is an involuntary creditor.

We have the insurance company who provided insurance because the debtor could not get it in the market, and it was an assignment through the assigned risk pool, so as an involuntary creditor Hartford had to continue to provide the insurance.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Even when the premiums were not paid?
Without--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Once the premiums were not paid, the Hartford then went and issued a default notice to the debtor--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --No, my question is this.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Let's assume the current premium has not been paid.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Does Hartford, under Missouri law, have the requirement to continue to provide the coverage?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: For a period of time, yes, because--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: How long?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --contractually there is a 30-day notice period before the policy can be cancelled.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: For just 30 days?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: That's what the contract provides.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you seek for some 6 or 7 months, am I right?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but what happened during that period of time was that initially a part of the premium was paid when the application for the insurance was submitted, so that was covered for a period of time.
The way these policies work--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --up front.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --I believe it was over $25,000.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could not the insurer have said in a situation like this, the debtor is in Chapter 11, I'm not going to be at risk, put up the whole thing in front?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: If we had known about the Chapter 11, perhaps we could have done that, but we did not know, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: As soon as you found out about it, couldn't you say, at this point we stop until you pay the premium in advance?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: We did not find out until after the policy was terminated, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: How does that relate to your argument that you were required to provide insurance anyway because this individual, or the company would have been within the assigned risk pool?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, what happened was that they tendered their application with part of the premium, and then the... a period of time went by.
Premiums are calculated on an audit basis, meaning the debtor has to submit their payroll reports to the insurer.
Then the insurer calculates the premiums based upon the number of persons who are employed times a certain rate.
The debtor in this case neglected to send those monthly reports, so Hartford sent an auditor in.
The auditor conducted the audit, went back to Hartford, Hartford calculated the premium and then sent a demand to the debtor.
The debtor paid part of the premium.
Now, all of this took a lot of time to happen.

After the debtor paid a part of the premium, the second installment, in addition to the one that was with the initial application, it was not enough to carry through the term, but by the time the Hartford went and said, you haven't paid the full amount, we were 30 days away from the termination of the policy, so it was too late to cancel.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So all you're saying is, we had to start insuring.
When we could stop insuring was in fact a complex function of the audit.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Could I ask you about section 506, which is on page 2 of your brief?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It says the trustee may recover necessary costs and expenses of preserving or disposing.
Now, I assume that he can't recover them until they've been expended.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: When the trustee... the trustee--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --That's a reasonable reading of it.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't it also a reasonable reading of it that he can't recover them unless he has expended them?
I mean, I'm--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When the trustee--
--Well, but that's not the position you're taking.
In response to other questions here, you have assumed that the trustee could sue to recover money that he didn't expend but that you expended.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --I think that the best reading of the statute, Your Honor, on its plain meaning, is that the trustee, when the trustee expends, then the trustee recovers.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: But under prior practice, that was not necessarily the rule.
Under prior practice, trustees could recover whether they expended or not, and individual claimants could recover whether they expended or not, and the problem that the court faces--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So long as somebody else had expended.
I mean, somebody has to have expended.
You acknowledge--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Somebody has to be out some dollars before they can recover, and it has to be an administrative, allowable administrative expense before you get to 506(c).

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You agree that the most straightforward reading of the statute is that the trustee can recover any money that he's expended--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --in securing the--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, but that doesn't, of course, tell us what to do when the trustee has not expended and the individual claimant is out--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --You would agree, Mr. Brownlee, that the standard situation in which 506 applies is where the trustee has paid out cash, and--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Where the trustee has paid out cash--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --and then he gets back that cash from the security, from the sale of the secured property.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Correct, Your Honor, and that has always been the uniform rule in the Federal courts including as articulated by this Court.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So how often has 506 applied to credit transactions?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: It applies in almost every single case, Your Honor, in one way or another, where there is a secured party.
The problem that we face, Your Honor, is that in some cases--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: No, I mean practically.
You've just said the standard instance in which 506 is used is, the trustee pays out dollars, and then the property is sold, and he gets those dollars back from the top of the price.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Correct, but that presupposes, Your Honor, that the trustee paid the expense first, and that presupposes the trustee had funds, unencumbered funds to pay these--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: All I'm suggesting is that that is the core situation to which 506 applies.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --It is the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought you agreed with me.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --It is the logical situation, the paradigm which Congress seemed to have had in mind, and now what we must do is fill in the gap for the part that Congress didn't seem to have in mind, and so the question becomes, do we follow the pre-code practice to fill the gap?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, that's... you know, you keep talking about pre-code practice, and I looked at your cases, and there isn't all that pre-code practice.
I mean, there's the one decision that you're relying on from this Court before there was any bankruptcy legislation, and then another one that's an admiralty case.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: The Poznan case was an admiralty case, that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That doesn't show a very solid pre-code practice.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the case which we rely on from this Court, the Wilson case, I think quite clearly addressed the specific problem and provided the specific solution that we're seeking.

In the lower court decisions, as the bankruptcy laws evolved up to the point of the Bankruptcy Code, those courts relied on Wilson for the proposition that the administrative claimant has the right to come to the court and have its claim paid when it has not been paid, and one of the cases that we cite in our brief is a case involving... bear with me for one minute, Your Honor.

It is the Louisville case, Louisville Storage Company case, 21 F. Supp. at 897, where the Court, citing Wilson, said, quote, it has always been the rule, inherent in general principles of equity, that the lienholder must bear the expense of bankruptcy administration, which is solely for his benefit, or to which he consents, or to which he causes, and there, and in those other cases relying on Wilson, the courts would allow on occasion the unpaid administrative claimant to come forward and have their claim paid.
So Wilson is the lodestar, in a sense, and the lower Federal courts followed it.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, but you're relying on one rather old Supreme Court decision and some lower court decisions following it up.
I'm just suggesting that that is not a very strong peg for claiming this understood pre-code practice.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, it was uniform.

There were no opinions to the contrary, and the... this practice, I would submit, Your Honor, is more established than the pre-code practice which this Court was willing to accept in Midlantic for the proposition that a trustee's power to abandon carries with it the corollary that the trustee cannot abandon in violation of certain health and safety requirements under applicable State law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, isn't it possible Congress might have wanted to change this, figuring that what you describe as pre-code practice would attract a certain amount of leeches who wanted to get at the secured property?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the rule, I think, is one which initially five courts of appeals, and the Eighth Circuit changed its mind, had adopted and the courts had no ability administering.
I don't think there's any evidence, Your Honor, that Congress intended to change the practice.

In fact, the only evidence in the legislative history is that Congress intended to maintain the status quo, so there's no... there being no evidence of an intent to change, the presumption, I think, is that, and properly so, given the nature of what we're talking about, the bankruptcy laws, that the pre-code practice endures.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If the trustee chose to seek these funds to surcharge the property and, either by an accounting entry or by the actual receipt of cash, received $25,000, would that be paid 100 percent to you, or could the trustee say, well now, I have my own administrative expenses, too, and other, and there are other administrative... how does that work?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: If the trustee has paid the claim from unencumbered funds of the estate, and the trustee then seeks to recover it from the secured party's collateral, and the trustee is basically replenishing the estate and then the funds would be distributed, but in that situation, of course, the administrative claimant is paid in full--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but in my hypothetical he's not quite sure, and so he goes to court seeking authority to pay.
He gets it.
Does that go just to you, or does it go to other administrative claimants as well?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --It would go to us if we were the only section 506--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, there are other ones.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, those claimants' claims are not entitled to the priority that section 506(c) provides.
If those claims did not provide a benefit to the secured party--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: They say they did.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Oh, if they did, and they were properly also 506(c) claimants--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: They claim that, but he just seeks authority to recover the money for you, and then it's there in the pot.
Doesn't everybody get to share it?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --If those other claimants' claims were determined ultimately by the court to be entitled to 506(c), we would share with other 506(c) claimants.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Do you have to do that under your theory of the case, where you yourself can sue?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So once you get a surcharge you have to share it with everybody else?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: I think it's important to understand, Your Honor, that in the bankruptcy case the timing of when claims are presented is not what's important.
At the end of the case, after all claims have been cut off by a bar date and then determined, those... that is when the distributions can be made.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I know.
Well, you help me with my question.
What happens if you prevail and you succeed in a surcharge?
Do you have to share with other administrative claimants who have made a claim?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: If they have 506(c) rights, yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Now, are there priorities within the 506(c) administrative claimants?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: No.
All 506(c) claimants are equal.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Including those pre-conversion and post conversion?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: No. 506(c) only applies, Your Honor, to post petition.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ah.
Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What happens pre-petition if a debtor has a huge claim against, say, General Motors that requires a lawsuit, let's say, millions of dollars, and the trustee, thinking it isn't that great a claim, won't bring the lawsuit--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --but the creditor, who's a big creditor--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --thinks I'd certainly like this money in the estate--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I want him to bring the lawsuit.
What happens?
Can the creditor sue General Motors directly?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, we believe that the Court answered that question in Meyer v. Flemming--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, and what's the answer?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --which is cited in our brief, and the answer is that of course the lawsuit should not be allowed to lapse.
The creditor can come and bring the cause of action.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So the creditor can bring his own lawsuit in that case for the benefit of the estate because the trustee wouldn't.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And you say that's really the same principle here.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor, and I think--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What could Hartford have done here to protect itself?
I mean, what's conceivably--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Conceivably--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --out there to protect Hartford?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is no notice required to be given to people post petition in a Chapter 11?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Notice is required, Your Honor.
It should have been done.
It was not done in this case to the Hartford, so the Hartford was without notice.
But let's... assuming that Hartford had notice, what could Hartford have done?
Well, being an involuntary creditor, and having to provide insurance as long as the premium was paid, very little, and Hartford's relief is section 506(c).

Just like when the United States comes in and cleans up an environmental site post petition, and the cleanup of the site benefits the secured party by increasing the value of the collateral, the United States in that situation, courts have recognized, can then come to court and say, the trustee has not paid our administrative expense for cleanup because the trustee has no unencumbered funds to do so and the courts have said, well, you may surcharge the collateral to the extent that it benefited the secured party.

Now, if that were not the rule, and the trustee had no funds to pay the United States' cleanup cost, then essentially the United States would be subsidizing the recovery of the secured party, who would walk away with the full value of the collateral, having the benefit of the cleanup cost, but not have to pay that cost from the collateral, and this Court's principle, which is... it's articulated in Burnham v. Bowen, in Wilson, a whole line of cases, is that that is not the bankruptcy rule.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Was this property... was the business ultimately sold as a going concern here?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
During the case... the stores were sold during the course of the Chapter 11 case.
In fact, that was planned from the beginning.

In our appendix there is, at one of the pull-outs that we have, which shows the budget and what the parties were to expend, listed at the top... and this is page 175a... you will see at the top, stores to close, and this was the exhibit that was attached to the order on the first day of the bankruptcy, and it shows that there were... identifies a number of stores to be closed, and in fact a number of the stores were closed and sold as going concerns, and the bank realized the proceeds from those sales, so the bank got the benefit of the going concern, and our simple point is that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But a number of them weren't.
I mean, the thing eventually ended up in Chapter 7, and it was liquidated.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --After the stores were sold--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: All of them?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --I believe all of them.
There may have been one or so, but--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Brunstad--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --No, all of them were, Your Honor.
Yes, all of them were.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Mr. Brunstad, in Midlantic, which you say is the case that stands for the proposition of bringing forward pre-code practice if Congress doesn't... we said in codifying the judicially developed rule of abandonment, Congress also presumably included the established corollary, et cetera.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, what rule are you saying that 506(c) codified that should bring with it your position?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: 506(c) codified the tip of the iceberg of the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, the tip of the iceberg really isn't a very... I mean--

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Certainly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --It's certainly... Midlantic is much narrower than saying the statutory... is just the tip of the iceberg, that we bring all sorts of other things with it.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think, Your Honor, in this case, what should come with 506(c) is the undisputed established pre-code practice.
There is no contrary precedent, contrary to Wilson.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but it's... Midlantic is talking about, they're codifying something and you can tell from the language of the section that they're codifying it.
You can't tell from 506(c) that they're codifying anything as broad as you say, it seems to me.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the bankruptcy codifies in section 553 rights of set-off.

That says nothing about rights of recoupment, yet in bankruptcy that was an established right and this Court in Ritter v. Cooper said it's well-settled that recoupment applies in bankruptcy, so this Court in construing the bankruptcy laws has not been shy about incorporating and recognizing its--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but set-off and recoupment seem much closer to one another than 506(c) and what you're talking about.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, I think, Your Honor, that actually the opposite is true, and what we're talking about here is a rule that the administrative claimant can come, which is inextricably intertwined with the right of the trustee.
The general principle is the same.

I think it's important to emphasize that bankruptcy proceedings are in rem, and that the bankruptcy court, as this Court made clear in the Adair case, that it is the responsibility of the court, the bankruptcy court to see to it that the in rem assets, which are in custodia legis, are, in fact, distributed properly.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but that's a general statement that really I don't see... how does that aid you in this particular case, when you're talking about 506(c)?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Because Adair is the case, Your Honor, which articulated the rule which we're relying on here, the general rule that the administrative expenses must be paid out of the secured party's collateral to the extent of the benefit and the court... it would I think be... lead to an absurd result to say that if the trustee doesn't come to court, that the bankruptcy court has no authority to allocate the charges properly, and if the bankruptcy court has authority to do so, any party in interest in the case should be able to come to court to say to the court, this is how it must be done.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that would be all the more so if you interpreted 506(c) as allowing the trustee to recover only those expenses that he has paid.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I think your case gets harder if you read 506(c) to say that the trustee may also recover on your behalf expenses that you've paid.
I don't read it that way, but you apparently do.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think Your Honor's reading is the correct reading.
In response to Your Honor's prior question I think it was... my response was that pre-code practice allowed either way.
I think Your Honor's reading is the best reading, and that the administrative claimant, following pre-code practice, can come to court when the trustee has not paid the claim.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under what section?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Under what section, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the bank... under pre-code practice, the lower courts often would invoke this rule as a gloss on the court's power to allow administrative claims in addition.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But to me that is the difficulty with your position, and the cases where we've said pre-code practice, you can point to a section and say, yes, this brings... this says (a), but it also means the corollary to (a) under prior practice, but you don't have an alternative section to point to.
506(c) doesn't help you.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, neither does the doctrine of recoupment, Your Honor, or the doctrine of ear-marking or substantive consolidation, and those are all equitable doctrines which endure under the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Brownlee, I'm not... you made a major shift from your brief in response to Justice Scalia's question, and so I'd really like to know what your position is.
That is, you made a big thing about 50(c)... it wasn't the trustee only.
It was the trustee and Carrot Mark... your client, but now you say Justice Scalia has the better reading and 506 has nothing to do with this case, so which one is it?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --It does, Your Honor, because 506(c) clearly recognizes that expenses of the kind which we are talking about are chargeable against the secured party's collateral, and the question in an in rem bankruptcy proceeding where we're simply talking about dividing up assets, who's going to get what, the question is, can a party in interest come to court and say, this expense should be put in this bucket, or moved here, because the trustee has no incentive or ability to come to court to say it should be so.

And where the... because the bankruptcy court has the power under 105, under its general equitable powers, which this Court recognized recently in the energy resources cases to be quite broad, to allocate--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Are you dropping your reliance on 506?

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
506(c) recognizes that the expense of the kind which we are talking about here is chargeable.

All we are saying is simply, the Court should adopt the gloss which the courts adopted pre-enactment of the bankruptcy code, that individual claimants, parties at interest, unpaid administrative claimants can come to court and say, the trustee won't act, we get to have this particular expense--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Come to court under 506(c)?
Because that's the question presented in your petition for certiorari.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: --The Court, under 506(c), following pre-code practice, could rule, and... I think it doesn't make any difference, Your Honor, whether you rely on 506(c) directly or on pre-code practice, but I think that you can rely on section 506(c).

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if you can't, you lose on the question presented.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Well, our position, Your Honor, is that you can.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your time has expired.

turn.speaker: g_eric_brunstad_jr
turn.label: Mr. G. Eric Brunstad, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear now from you, Mr. Brownlee.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Good morning, Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
I don't know if it would make any difference in the Justices' rulings, but I'd like to... my friend and colleague Mr. Brunstad misspoke on a couple of questions, one I believe by Justice Kennedy.
I may be wrong about that, because I think it was the first question in the argument, where Hartford indicated it had asked the trustee to proceed and the trustee had refused.

In the blue brief at page 5, note 4, it is stated, Hartford did not request the trustee to pursue its claim under section 506(c) because the law in the Eighth Circuit as it existed at that time permitted administrative claimants to pursue such claims on their own behalf, citing the Boatmen's case, which was overruled by the Eighth Circuit.
In fact, not even that is really so.

When the Boatmen's case was decided, the one that was overruled in this case, the issue was at contest in the Hartford v. Magna case, Magna being the predecessor of my client, so I believe Mr. Brunstad misspoke in response to the answer to that question.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, how could Hartford have avoided losing its claim here, do you think, if there was something that was obtained when the business was sold as an ongoing business, and assuming that the Workman's Comp insurance somehow benefited the property?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, Hartford's policies were such in this case... you can look at the record below... that it did not know that it was insuring a debtor for a period of some 15 months or so.

The one thing Hartford could have done, I believe, although I don't intend to tell them how to run their business in any... and I don't mean this in any way derogatorily or in a pejorative manner... would have been to have some procedures in place so that they would have known, even though the debtor... I have no evidence that the debtor did notify them.
Bankruptcy is and always has been somewhat creditor emptor, and it is true in this case that there's no evidence that Hartford was actually notified.
There is evidence in this case on the record below that Hartford knew that it had a series of quarterly bills that were going unpaid, and so it couldn't have found out.

Had Hartford known earlier, before the case was converted to a 7, and before the case was in a total liquidation mode, Hartford could have come to court, Hartford could have asked to terminate the policy based on nonpayment, at least cut its losses, and also Hartford could have tried to take steps to persuade the bankruptcy court perhaps while there were still funds in the estate to allow it within an administrative claim and force the payment of that claim.
Bankruptcy has a lot to do with timing, especially in a reorganization case that's going downhill.
Hartford in fact is correct that it did not know until substantially later.

If the Justice's question is, how could Hartford have protected itself after the fact, once we got to March of 1993, or whatever the record will show the date was that it learned, Hartford cannot protect itself under 506(c), I submit.
506(c) says the trustee may recover.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, what happens in... I don't know that that Meyer case really answers the question, but what happens in the case of a pre-petition, a pre-petition debtor, the pre-petition debtor has a giant claim against General Motors, a lawsuit--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and the trustee doesn't bring the claim, and one of the creditors says, I'd like to bring it.
Now, Meyer dealt with the case of the debtor having filed the suit, not a creditor.
It could be taken as authority for the creditor.
So what happens?
Is it the case that creditors in such circumstances simply go and bring their own lawsuits in the name of the estate instead of the trustee doing it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Well, Justice Breyer, if I could just observe first of all in the Meyer case, it's my reading of the Meyer case that while the Court allowed the principle of the second debtor to proceed with the prefiled proof of claim in the first bankruptcy, it was clear that any recovery would be on behalf of the estate, which is not something that Hartford seeks here.
Hartford seeks a nonshare.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I know, but what I'm trying to do for my own purposes is to find an analogy, and I know it's a rough analogy, but I would like to know just for my own purposes what happens, and it must happen often, of when a trustee doesn't bring a lawsuit to get some money for the estate, that a big creditor thinks he ought to bring.
Does bankruptcy normally work... this can't be unusual.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: It's not unusual.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And in such circumstances there are two possibilities.
One is that you bring a suit to sue the trustee and make him do it.
Another possibility is, you bring your own lawsuit but it... somehow you're standing in the shoes of the trustee.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Both exist.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Both exist.
All right.
If the--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: You can file a motion--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Fine.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --in the bankruptcy court to compel the trustee to act--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --or you can seek what is known in many of the cases as derivative standing.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Fine.
Now, if that's so in that circumstance, why shouldn't that be so in this circumstance?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Because in this circumstance Hartford didn't follow that procedure.
Hartford didn't ask the trustee to act.

Hartford didn't ask the bankruptcy court to force the trustee to act, and Hartford didn't go to the bankruptcy court having made a record on that subject and said, you know, somebody needs to sue Union Planters because we think there's a pretty good 506(c) claim--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And now, in your view as a bankruptcy lawyer, if they had, I mean, is that a good way to resolve the problem?
You say, look, you're a creditor.
You're a post petition creditor.

You have a right to get your money, but you'll have to go first to the trustee, because otherwise there are going to be those leeches, you know, or there are going to be all these people running around.
Is that a good resolution?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Well, Justice, it's not the leeches issue, it's the quality-of-distribution-among-creditors-of-equal-rank issue.

If the trustee, who is clothed under 506(c) with the responsibility to pursue this right, this action to obtain funds that were otherwise the property of the secured creditor, either doesn't proceed in her own behalf, or there isn't a court order that allows whatever surrogate, Hartford or whomever, to proceed in the name of the estate and on behalf of the estate, then you're going to have a circumstance where that recovery is going to be, as Hartford seeks here, kept to itself and not shared with other creditors of equal rank.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Where does--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Well, can't--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --the court have the authority to allow Hartford to proceed, under what section of the code?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: There is none.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Hartford--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I'm not aware of a statutory basis, Justice, for derivative standing.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --All right, but--

--I thought that in response to Justice Breyer you said, now, you go to the trustee and the court, and if the trustee doesn't want to do it, then you ask the court for authority to do it on your own, but now you're saying that a court doesn't have... can't allow you to do it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: The bankruptcy courts have developed a body of law wherein they will... some will grant what is called derivative standing, and the cases are cited in the briefs.

As a matter of fact, the best example of them is in the amici for the petitioner, when the AIA and the National Union suggests that even under the preference section and the fraudulent conveyance sections, which also start with the words, the trustee may recover, that there are cases which have allowed third parties--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Are those proper cases, and proper holdings in your view?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Justice, I don't think... I know that this Court doesn't need to decide whether derivative standing is appropriate on a Nation-wide basis for us to win this case, because I don't think this Court should hold, and I hope it doesn't hold the 506(c), the word trustee means anything other than trustee.
I don't think you should hold that it means... because I don't think there is any established pre-code practice and, if there were, the statute is sufficiently clear.
It shouldn't--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, then I'm not sure why your answer to Justice Breyer isn't that the Hartford goes to the Court, it asks to order the trustee, if the court and the trustee give no relief, there's nothing Hartford can do.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Well, Justice Breyer--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I don't know why you didn't say it that way.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --I understood asked me a factual question, Justice Kennedy.
I don't mean to argue with you.

In practice, and I'm in the trenches a heck of a lot more than I'm in the appellate courts, in practice bankruptcy courts will occasionally, if a trustee refuses to act, call a creditor or another party with the right to act in the estate's name on behalf of the estate to pursue the claim if the court feels that it should--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is that pursuit in the bankruptcy court--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --In the bankruptcy--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --or in the plenary action?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --In the bankruptcy court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In the bankruptcy--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Now, there is another--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --If we assume that is correct, then, if we assume that is a proper practice, then if Hartford had done two things differently, Hartford would be entitled to recover, I take it, on the assumption that there may be a derivative action, and the two different things are, number 1, Hartford would have to have gone to the trustee, and the trustee would have had to indicate refusal.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And number 2, Hartford, in bringing its suit, would have to have captioned it, Hartford ex rel, or Trustee ex rel Hartford, rather than Hartford, and if those two facts had been different, assuming derivative actions are appropriate, Hartford could recover here.
Am I right, or am I missing something?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I don't precisely disagree with the way it's phrased, Justice Souter.
You're basically right.
Hartford would have had to get a court order that said, that established the trustee was not proceeding--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
Now, why does it have to get the court order if there's no statutory section on it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --I'm not here to argue whether derivative standing is the right approach.
Every bankruptcy court--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right, but if we assume derivative standing is... I'm making that assumption... what difference does it make whether Hartford gets the court order or doesn't get the court order?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Because--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is it merely orderly procedure?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --No, because if Hartford recovers it has to share with all other creditors of equal rank.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, Hartford has indicated that that's exactly what it will do, although that's I guess an easy concession, because it says there aren't any.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: If you could hear me for a minute on that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I believe your question earlier to Mr. Brunstad was pre-conversion or post conversion, and his answer was pre-petition or post petition.
Those are big differences.
There aren't any administrative creditors pre-petition.
Pre-conversion and post conversion--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ah.
Ah, okay.
You're right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --in an 11 that goes to a 7, there can be a bundle of administrative creditors on both sides.
In fact, under 726(b) of the Bankruptcy Code, the post conversion administrative creditors in fact do have a priority, so--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --while he says there wouldn't be any others, that's not so--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Okay.
Let's assume for the sake of argument, then, that I misspoke or he misspoke on that.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --He did misspeak.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He's... I will make the further assumption that any recovery would be subject to the claims of all others in the same class that Hartford is in.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Now, if that would be the legal effect of Hartford's recovery here, is the only thing, then, that prevents Hartford from doing that the failure of Hartford to have gone to the trustee in the first place and said, let me bring a derivative action?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: If you are in a district where a judge will allow derivative standing in the name of the trustee, that's correct, because 506(c) talks about an action to recover by the trustee.
The bankruptcy court in a number of districts will allow that.
In a number of districts, some bankruptcy courts are critical of that.
But in any event, Hartford came here, and there has been I think a shift in the briefs, quite frankly, as I understand the argument, or maybe I just misperceived it.

Hartford came here on the merits briefs to ask the court assembled to rule that under 506(c)'s meaning, 506(c) could deemed to say, the trustee may recover, da-da, da-da, comma, and any unpaid administrative creditor may also recover under this section, and if that unpaid administrative creditor does recover under this section, it will have a super priority claim over all other administrative creditors as described in section 507(a).

Now, that's a big mouthful, but from a little section that says the trustee may recover, for Hartford to win on the merits briefs, all those things I just said, I respectfully submit, have to be engrafted onto a simple statute that gives the trustee in bankruptcy under limited circumstances as defined under the merits the right to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr.--
--Does the record tell us whether there are other administrative creditors now competing for this money?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --It does not, Justice Stevens, and I did not have the case below--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I had understood the record to indicate that this was the only administrative creditor, and that in no event would there be money available for any other, either general creditors or post petition creditors.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --I can tell you this, Justice Stevens... I did not have the case below, so I'm not going to tell you something I don't know, obviously.
We called up from the archives the final report.
The final report doesn't say, so I can't tell you that.
I can tell you that Union Planners' predecessor had a $4 million loan, we lost a million and a half in principal, all of our interest, and all of our attorney's fees and costs.
If there was any other administrative creditor in the case, they didn't get paid.
Now, whether, as a matter of fact, there was another group there is unknown.

Intuitively, I would suggest to the court that Hartford went to a lot of trouble to make this end run if it was the only unpaid administrative creditor, because it could have made a simple demand on the trustee and taken its shot for derivative standing, and I would also like to suggest something else--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, but let me just--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Go ahead, Justice Stevens.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --One other question.
Am I correct in assuming that they did satisfy the requirements of 503(a) and (b)?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: They satisfied the requirements of 503(a) in that they... I'm trying to think which is which.
They made... in the same motion that they sued under 506(c), they made a request for payment of their administrative claim, and I believe they made a--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The bankruptcy judge allowed it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Yes, and I made... I believe they made a request for allowance and payment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: So I... it's my belief that they did follow 503 at least.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You see, the thing that troubles me about your position... it's a very difficult case, but the thing that troubles me about your position is, it seems to me it makes 503(a) and (b) meaningless.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Well, let me try to respond to that.
503(a) says you can file a request for an administrative claim or you can file a request for a payment of it, and that's fine.
I mean, any creditor ought to be able to file a proof of claim.
Unsecured creditors can.
Secured creditors can.
I certainly couldn't imagine why administrative creditors shouldn't be allowed to.
Anybody can ask for payment from the estate, but 503 talks about a direction to the estate to seek payment.
Creditors can't typically sue secured creditors as if they could sue outside under State law, to go back to a question you previously asked, Justice.

Within the bankruptcy, the Bankruptcy Code's... I believe the Court's language in some cases in looking at plain meaning has been a consistent and coherent scheme, has been that creditors deal with the estate, and the estate deals with creditors.
Hartford wants to deal with us.

They want to call us outside, and they don't have any way to do that except to make the argument that's made on the merits briefs and partially made today, although there may have been a shift in argument, that they can do it under 506(c).

Now, I would suggest to the Court that the Congress was not totally unmindful when it adopted the code of the possibility that inter... that there might be intercreditor fights under some circumstances, under some hypotheticals.

In fact, Congress enacted section 510, and in 510(c), which is the equitable subordination section, the Congress said that on application to a court, after noticing a hearing, the court can subordinate all or part of one creditor's claim to all or part of another creditor's claim, or give the lien to the estate if it wanted, under general principles of equitable subordination.

Now, the rule isn't the same as the substantive rule the trustee must meet to recover ordinary and necessary expenses of preserving the estate and benefit of the creditor under 506(c), but 510(c) does provide a remedy, but Hartford wasn't willing to share.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is it ever used in these administrative expense areas, that section, 510?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: It's used a lot in winner liability type claims, or any kind of claim where you've got some sort of equitable misconduct, Justice O'Connor.
I have not personally, and I... that doesn't mean it's not used, and I have not researched the issue.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What about the--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I do not know how often it is used.
Yes, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Mr. Brownlee, what about the suggestions that petitioner made of the clean-up costs, or even the Government.
It's an ongoing operation, and there are tax liabilities.
She said that your position means that a Good Samaritan, or a Government agency who comes in and cleans up the toxic junk gets nothing--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --and the Government would get no tax.
How do you deal with those cases?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Well, in the first place, in terms of... and I gather your question is, a volunteer comes along post petition and cleans up the property, which directly benefits the property, or the secured creditor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, he... I'm addressing... I don't remember precisely how he put it in his brief.
I'm sure you focused on it, so you remember better than I do.
He talked about--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I'm not sure about that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --the clean-up costs that could be incurred by a private contractor or by a Government agency to decontaminate the property.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Well, if the case is in a Chapter 7, the case is--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: This... it has to be--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --when it was in 11, because that's what made it possible for the thing to go on.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: If the case is in Chapter 11, and the debtor hires a private contractor to come in and clean up dirty property, and that contractor does it, and the court finds that the reasonable and necessary, all of that is met, which it obviously sounds like on those facts, most bankruptcy courts would find that, and the estate becomes insolvent, and the contractor has not protected itself and gotten paid, then the contractor is his administrative claimant in the bankruptcy and is treated of equal rank with all others, and if that's unfortunate, and that means the statute's broke, then the Congress ought to fix the statute.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So you would... that's a very candid answer.
It wouldn't make any difference whether a Government agency came in to do the clean-up, having been authorized by the debtor?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I'm not aware, Justice Ginsburg, of any super priority for administrative creditors inter se under the 507 priorities of the Bankruptcy Code, except for the one that Hartford asks you today to judicially engraft onto a statute which only provides for the trustee to recover.
I'm not aware of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is it the case that if the trustee... the trustee himself goes and brings this lawsuit against Justice... she can do it.
I mean, the trustee can do this under 506(c).

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And, say, collects $10 million, which happened to be the cost of the contracted-for clean-up.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So now there's $10 million in the trustee's hand.
Now, there are another $20 million of administrative expenses that were not related to preserving the property.

Now, does that $10 million... does the trustee give that $10 million to the toxic waste contractor that helped to preserve the property, or does that toxic waste contractor get only one-third and two-thirds has to go to these other administrative claimants who had nothing to do with preserving the property?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: It's even worse, Justice Breyer.
First, the trustee takes the trustee's fees and expenses and expenses of counsel off the top--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, that's all right.
I don't object to find--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --And then it goes two-thirds, one-third.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --It does.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I am not aware of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But then there's... that--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Unless there--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Make sure I don't misspeak as an officer of the court.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, mm-hmm.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Unless there is some Federal statute that grants a priority outside of bankruptcy to clean up contractors because of the importance of the environmental laws, where you'd have a clash between Federal statutes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So then this is a bigger--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I'm not aware of a bankruptcy priority.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --All right, so the... (c) has as its purpose simply getting money from the secured creditor into the estate.
It doesn't have as its purpose giving that money to the people who incurred the expense.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Oh, no, Your Honor.
Distribution--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is different.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
