turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --is governed by 726--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Wow.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --in a liquidation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And what was the prior practice?
Was the prior practice that when the... our secured toxic waste person... nonsecured, sorry.
The toxic waste person sues against the collateral, and apparently can get the money.
Did that toxic waste person get to keep the whole thing, or did the toxic waste person have to put it in the estate and share it with the other nonrelated administrative claimants?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I am not sure that I'm aware of a toxic waste case pre--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no, it wouldn't have been toxic waste.
What I mean is, a person--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Certainly not in the 1800's.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --A 506(c)... a 506(c) creditor, and then there are non-506(c)'s, but 503(a) creditors, and when the 506(c) creditor brought the suit... I know there wasn't a 506(c) at that time--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I didn't mean to be cute.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --but I mean, that kind of a person brings the suit, collects the $10 million, did he get to keep the whole $10 million, or did he have to throw it in the pool and he only got one-third and the non-506(c) administrative creditors got two-thirds?
What happened?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: My best answer, and I don't want you to think this is a dodge, because I don't mean it to be, is it's my understanding of the pre-code practice was that it was all over the lot in terms of the equitable rule--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So this is quite--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --what the judges decided to do.
We cited at page 44 of the red brief an article by Toth which recounts some of the history to the... the article itself is in the West New England Law Review.

It recounts a lot of the history to the predecessor to 506(c), and in that article it concludes that, as Collier's did in 1978, which we also cite on that page, that there was no firmly established rule as--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Why would you want to allow such a person, i.e., a 506(c) person, to get from the secured creditor money that he isn't going to keep and he in fact is going to give to two other people--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --who, vis-a-vis the secured creditor, shouldn't get it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --Because, Justice... because of the equality of distribution rules of the Bankruptcy Code.
There are administrative claim creditors, and there is not a super priority that says you're a 506(c) creditor, because creditors don't have the right to pursue the action under 506(c).
Congress never intended 506(c)--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: My question is--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --to be... allow you to bring that case.
It was for the trustee only, so a fortiori it was to be distributed to all the creditors of equal rank, and that's what Congress decided in 1978.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Mr. Brownlee--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Yes, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --my question is related, and it seemed to me in reading the text of 506(c) and 503 that not every administrative expense under 503(a) would fit under 506.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I agree with that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: 506 is limited to the reasonable, necessary costs and expenses of preserving or disposing of the secured property.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I agree with Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And presumably some wages and salaries don't fit under that.
Maybe some insurance premiums don't fit under that.
It would depend on what it was.
Am I right?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Yes, you're absolutely right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Mr. Brownlee, going--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --I mean, I could see that 506(c) would be related to things like painting the building, or paying the real estate commission to sell it.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Your Honor, I know you're way past this, but I wished at one point you'd been a bankruptcy judge in our district.
I couldn't agree with you more.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, let me--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: But some courts will find an implied benefit, or find some reason--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But wait a minute--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --to try to toss these things into 506(c) on the merits.
That's not the case here we're talking about.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But let's clarify one thing here.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Yes, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought you had agreed that if this action had been brought by the trustee, because the trustee had expended this very money, 506(c) would apply.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: If this action had been brought by the trustee--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the fact that it's insurance premiums doesn't distinguish it from paint on the buildings.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --We fought it below.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you lost on it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: And we lost.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I don't think we'd lose in every court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but for the purposes of our decision--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: For the purpose of this case--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --we assume that this is just like paint on the buildings or something like that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mr. Brownlee--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --You're absolutely right.
Yes, Justice.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --do you have this answer to Justice Breyer's one-third, two-third hypothetical?
I mean, it's a problem for your case, and I thought the answer might be this, but tell me if I'm wrong.
Assuming derivative standing... the premise of my other question.
Assume it again.

If the one administrative creditor has administrative standing, what he will do, I presume, is to bring an action on behalf of all administrative creditors, so he will not nearly collect his insurance premium.

He will collect the charges of all other administrative creditors, and therefore he will get in a... theoretically 100 percent of what is owed, and so he will get his one-third, and they will get their two-thirds, and everybody will be whole.
Is that the answer to the problem?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Well, if every administrative creditor qualified to be a surcharging creditor under the standards of 506(c)--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right.
Right, yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --But you're assuming every administrative creditor in the estate does so qualify, and I suggest to you that that hypothetically is an interesting question--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay, dumb assumption.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --but it doesn't happen in practice.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But to the extent that that assumption would be true, is that the way we avoid the one-third, two-third problem?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: To the extent that that assumption is true, if every administrative claim in a case qualifies for a surcharge... let me make sure I understand your hypothetical.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: And the trustee refuses to act, which is... I won't go into the inconceivability of that, because it would be such a large claim that very few trustees would not be highly incentivized, but if--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: We'll assume the trustee is broke and so on, but assume it anyway.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --If it was a large case the trustee would be fixing to get unbroke very quickly when she won, but I don't mean to argue.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Under that assumption, the trustee refuses to act, the bankruptcy court refuses to direct the trustee to act, the bankruptcy court refuses to appoint a new trustee who will act, and the bankruptcy decides, in the exercise of its discretion, without any direct statutory authority, to grant derivative standing, and the Hartford brings the claim in the name of the estate on behalf of all the administrative claims in the estate, and wins on the merits of the individual little lawsuits it will have to prove reasonable, necessary, direct benefit, secured creditor, if that's the hypothetical, then yes, they'll recover and you'll avoid the one-third, two-third problem.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Okay. Suppose a pipe in the building is leaking.
They need a plumbing contractor immediately, or the building's going to be wrecked.
You represent the plumbing contractor, and he comes to you and says, I want to be sure I get paid.
How... what are the different ways he can do it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: In practice?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: I'd call the bank.
I'd bypass the bankruptcy court entirely.
I'd call the bank and say--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And anything else--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --I'd call the bank and say, you're building's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --you're at risk of--

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --going to fall in and it's your collateral.
You want to give me the money, I'll fix it, and if you don't, I'll stand by and take a picture of it while it falls in.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --And anything else you're--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Anything else you're at risk of having to share with the other administrative creditors?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: Absolutely, Justice.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you... on what basis does the trustee have the right to sue for money that the trustee hasn't expended?

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: There is a line of authority, Justice Scalia, and it may be the better one.

It can be traced to the statement in, I believe, the floor reports in the legislative history that's in the briefs, where there's a reference to the moneys that the trustee has expended, or some phrase to that effect.
It escapes me, the precise phrasing.
It's that really 506(c) isn't intended to collect unpaid administrative claims.
It's intended only for the trustee to bring an action to recover those administrative claims that the trustee has paid out that justify to tag the bank to bring it back in and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_brownlee
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Brownlee
turn.text: --split up the deficiency.

That opinion was adopted in the plurality opinion in K & L Lakeland in the Fourth Circuit, but as I read that opinion there wasn't enough votes in the Fourth, even though the Fourth is a JKJ circuit, which was the other circuit on our side, other than this case, which I hope is affirmed at the end of this argument, to make that part of circuit law.

This Court doesn't have to decide that today, but I would agree with the Justice that that is a strong read of the real congressional meaning of the words, but the plain meaning of these words fit if you want to include an attack on unpaid administrative claims.
It just makes it real complicated, and it makes for the kinds of questions that we've discussed today.
If there are no further questions, Mr. Chief Justice--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Brownlee.
The case is submitted.
